utterances: Ron Rice is a city councilman from the ward where the murders took place.
In the days and weeks following the murders, he and Mayor Booker announced a dizzying number of programs.
Booker persuaded a local foundation to fund $3.2 million worth of surveillance cameras.
They improved recreation facilities for youth, boosted services for ex-cons and spent more on policing.
Booker held press conferences almost daily.
We have nothing short but the goal here in Newark, which is to rid our streets of illegal guns and the resulting gun violence in the city of Newark.
It paid off.
Murders are down by nearly 60 percent since Booker took office.
And this March, the city had its first murder-free month since 1966.
Crime rates have been falling in large cities all over the Western world.
But Todd Clear, dean of the Rutgers University School of Criminal Justice in Newark, says smaller poor Rust Belt cities haven't been able to replicate that success.
That makes Newark's turnaround even more remarkable.
We always used to map crimes by putting little colored pins in the wall.
But now we look at crime, really, we try to identify the people surrounding that place and identify how we can get the people who live there to become involved in solving the crime-related problems.
Clear says it's a combination of good policing and community outreach that's working in Newark.
Even a simple painting project is part of this mix.
At an elementary school on a recent Saturday, Towanda McEachern(ph) and her organization, Supporting our Sisters, are painting murals in the gym.
We may look at it as just painting the gym, or just painting the school.
The more kids in here, that's the less kids out there on the streets.
And in addition to that, they get an opportunity to do something for somebody else other than themselves.
It's not that community service is anything new here, but this is the first time in many years that local organizations, city agencies and the police are working together.
The 59 percent support Booker received yesterday shows he's still distrusted by many Newarkers.
He's often criticized as a carpetbagger from the suburbs who spends too much time outside the city hobnobbing with the rich and powerful.
But now, Booker has another four years in office, and as he pledged in the days after the 2007 murders, Newark is no longer defined by the violent crime that had held back its promise.
For NPR News, I'm Nancy Solomon.
Any politician knows the power of evangelical Christians on Election Day.
Traditionally, it's been Republicans who have laid claim to that powerful voting block.
Now Democratic Senator Barack Obama is calling on his party to reach out to Evangelicals.
He did so, at a recent speech to Call to Renewal - that's a group of churches and faith based organizations working to end poverty.
I think we make a mistake when we fail to acknowledge the power of faith in people's lives, in the lives of the American people.
I think it's time that we joined a serious debate about how to reconcile faith with our modern pluralistic society.
As part of our occasional conversations on the role of faith in our democracy, we turn to Senator Obama, who joins us from his office on Capitol Hill.
Good morning.
Good morning, Renee.
Throughout our history, a politician's faith and how it influences his politics has been a thorny issue, mostly for the politician himself or herself.
Why have you chosen this moment to wade into this issue?
Well, I think there's an interesting opportunity right now, Renee, partly because you're starting to see changes in leadership within the evangelical community.

You know, the traditional fire and brimstone leaders, the Jerry Falwells and the Pat Robertsons, are starting to give way to leaders like Rick Warren or TD Jakes, who, you know, still have conservative views when it comes to certain social issues, but are also opening up to issues like environmentalism or Darfur, the AIDS crisis in Africa.

And part of what I've wanted to make sure of is that those of us who consider ourselves progressive, that we are not somehow abandoning the opportunity to work with people of all faiths to bring about American renewal.

So are you talking, for instance, about, say, reaching out to very conservative Republican center, like Sam Brownback from Kansas, who sort of, on the one hand, led the charge on stopping the killing in Darfur, on slavery in Sudan, on helping persecuted Christians in - escape North Korea, and yet on the other hand he's a very, very strong and fierce opponent of a woman's right to choose abortion?
Well, I think Sam Brownback is a perfect example of the contradictory strains that we have in this country when it comes to faith and what those obligations are.
And Sam Brownback and I are not going to agree on abortion.
We're not going to agree on a constitutional amendment for gay marriage.
But he and I are the two chief co-sponsors on a bill dealing with Darfur.

And more than just the specific issue is involved, part of my intent in the speech was to figure out how can we stop using religion as a divisive force in the body politic and how can we tap into that sense that our values, our deepest moral commitments can be harnessed in order to bring about changes that might have seemed impossible if you were just looking at the realities of the here and now.

How does a Democrat, and especially one like yourself around who there has been speculation about your own ambitions, presidential ambitions, how do you deal with the suspicion that comes a Democrat's way when he or she speaks openly about their faith?
The suspicion that it is a calculated political move?
Is that...
Yeah.
Yeah.
Well, you know, one of the wonderful things about coming to Washington is realizing that everything you do is perceived as calculation.
So I, you know, I can't really spend a lot of time worrying about how my words are interpreted.
All I can do is make those words as true as possible.
But do you think that talking about your faith, or talking about one's faith for another, say, Democrat would have political value?
How are you?
Hello.
Well, not always perfectly.
Bernfield has Medicare and a supplemental policy from Harvard, where she last worked, for which she pays about $200 a month.
And she's been treated by a couple of doctors in New York who don't accept Medicare, so she had to pay upfront and wait for Medicare to reimburse her.
I walked out of one experience like that and said what if I couldn't pay?
Then would I have to go home and find another doctor who would take my Medicare?
And by this time, the problem that I have is going to grow, and it's really a significant problem.
Bernfield says she's not at all worried about claims that the bills now under consideration in Congress might cut back on her Medicare benefits.
She says she hates it when other people complain about all the things government can't do well.
In fact, public libraries are government, too, as are schools.
And we're very proud that we have them.
Meanwhile, Bernfield says she's happy with the way things are.
She has good medical care, satisfying work to do and time to spend with her children and grandchildren, whose pictures cover the top of a bureau in her bedroom.
This is my daughter-in-law and my grandson who's 4, and my sons.
So there's Jim, Camilla(ph) and Julian(ph).
She says she's loving watching her grandchildren grow.
And you never realize how kids look growing.
I mean, you miss six months, and you've missed a whole part of their lives.
So I hope Medicare stays healthy for a long, long time, because I'm planning to take advantage of it.
That was 71-year-old Audrey Bernfield.
Ballots in Arizona, Florida, and California include measures about same sex marriage.
In Arkansas, voters have already outlawed it.
This year, residents of that state will decide whether unmarried couples who live together can adopt kids or be foster parents.
Both supporters and opponents say the measure targets gay couples.
From member station KUAF in Fayetteville, Jacqueline Froelich reports.
Dave Hunter (ph) walks along Park Street in Fayetteville.
The 66-year-old married minister's canvassing against the ballot initiative.
Hello, good morning.
I'm Dave Hunter volunteering with Arkansas Families First.
Are you planning to vote on November 4th?
Absolutely.
That's 93-year-old Ellen Smith (ph), who answers the door in her flowered dressing gown.
She tells Hunter she'll vote against it.
I'm all for doing it.
I have a beautiful little granddaughter that my gay son and his partner have adopted, so I'm all for it.
If passed, Arkansas will join Utah as the only states to prohibit unmarried couples from adopting or fostering children.
Mississippi banned same-sex couple adoption eight years ago.
Florida barred single gays and lesbians from adopting.
But in Arkansas, momentum is building to block such a move.
Three weeks ago, under public pressure, the Arkansas Department of Human Services lifted its 10-year ban on unmarried couples serving as foster parents.
13 retired Arkansas judges, including three former state Supreme Court justices, oppose the measure.
Back in 2006, that court struck down a state policy banning same-sex foster parents.
All this frustrates Jerry Cox.
He's head of the Conservative Family Council Action Committee, which sponsored the November ballot initiative.
We said from the beginning that our purpose in passing this act was, number one, to protect child welfare.
But number two, we said that it was to blunt the gay agenda that wants to use foster care children and adoptive children as pawns in their effort to try to gain legitimacy for the gay lifestyle.
In 2004, Arkansans voted to ban gay marriage, but this measure?
It's not faring as well.
The latest non-partisan Arkansas poll found 55 percent oppose it.
The governor of Arkansas and other lawmakers have publicly denounced the ballot initiative.
Arkansas Families First campaign director Brett Kincaid says people are against it because it's anti-child.
The far right wing that's pushing this is trying to turn this into an argument about adult behavior.
They have a political agenda that they're trying to push, and unfortunately, they have decided to use children as pawns in that game.
Last year, 7,000 children entered state foster care, a one-quarter increase this decade.
At the same time, fewer foster parents have signed up to take kids home.
For NPR News, I'm Jacqueline Froelich in Fayetteville, Arkansas.
